The Numbers

Fylde Borough Council's spending data reveals £155 million in external payments across 37,514 transactions with 1,689 unique suppliers spanning April 2015 to March 2026 — an eleven-year dataset, the longest time series on the AI DOGE platform.

As a district council with an annual budget of approximately £10 million, Fylde is one of the smallest authorities in Lancashire. The borough covers the area around Lytham St Annes and Kirkham, handling housing, planning, waste collection, and leisure services.

Where the Money Goes

Fylde's spending data reveals some notable patterns. With 1,689 suppliers across eleven years, the council has a relatively narrow supplier base — though wider than neighbouring Wyre (1,558). The key concern is market structure rather than individual supplier dominance:

  • 4 category monopolies identified — service areas where a single supplier faces no competition
  • 10 threshold suspects — the highest count of any council on the platform, indicating payments clustered just below procurement thresholds

The combination of monopoly suppliers and threshold-clustering is a procurement risk pattern. When suppliers face no competition and payments are structured just below the level that triggers formal tender requirements, the conditions for poor value for money are established.

The Year-End Problem

Fylde has the second-highest year-end spending spike in Lancashire at 16.9x the monthly average. Only the county council's 14.7x figure is comparable in scale (and LCC's dataset covers a different time period).

A 16.9x March multiplier means the council processes nearly seventeen times more expenditure in the final month of the financial year than in a typical month. This is extreme even by local government standards and strongly suggests budget-rush behaviour — departments accelerating spending to avoid returning unspent allocations.

Red Flags in the Data

Fylde scores 64.7 out of 100 on our fraud triangle composite. The key findings beyond the year-end spike:

  • 10 threshold suspects — more than any other council, suggesting systematic structuring of payments below approval limits
  • 4 monopoly categories — service areas with zero competitive tension
  • 81 awarded contracts on Contracts Finder with an average publication delay of 37.5 days

The 37.5-day average publication delay is moderate — better than Blackburn with Darwen (69.8 days) but above the 30-day best practice target. Combined with the threshold suspects and monopolies, it suggests procurement governance that could be significantly tightened.

Eleven Years of Data

Fylde's dataset stretching back to April 2015 is uniquely valuable. It covers the full arc of recent local government finance: the final years of austerity, the COVID emergency, and the current cost-of-living pressures. Trend analysis across this period reveals how a small district council's spending priorities have shifted — and whether efficiency has improved or declined over the decade.

Political Context

Fylde Borough Council is controlled by the Conservatives. The borough is one of Lancashire's more affluent areas, with lower deprivation indices than East Lancashire councils.

Explore the full dataset on our Spending page, or see our DOGE Investigation for deeper analysis.
